title: 107_s1035
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Preservation Act". It includes findings related to the preservation of the Great Lakes. Congress finds that the Great Lakes are crucial public natural resources, providing safe drinking water for millions of people and supporting various economic activities in the region. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 serves as a framework for consultation on water diversion within the basin. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 allows for consultation on water diversion within the basin, with decisions made by the Governors of the Great Lakes States to protect water resources. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Administrator" refers to the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. "Bulk fresh water" is fresh water extracted for transportation without further processing. "From the Great Lakes basin" refers to water from specific lakes, interconnecting waterways, or tributaries. "Great Lake" includes Lake Erie and Lake Huron. The term "Great Lake" refers to Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan, Lake Ontario, and Lake Superior. The term "Great Lakes Province" refers to Ontario or Quebec in Canada, while the term "Great Lakes State" refers to Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, or Wisconsin. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service. SEC. 4. MORATORIUM ON EXPORT OF BULK FRESH WATER. Bulk fresh water from the Great Lakes basin shall not be exported from the United States. The moratorium will end when an approved mechanism for water decisions is in place. Congress suggests an agreement with Canada to uphold the moratorium. SEC. 5. PRESERVATION OF HISTORIC GREAT LAKES LIGHTHOUSES. The Great Lakes have influenced settlement, commerce, and recreation. Lighthouses in the region are historically significant but face neglect. A study will be conducted to preserve them within 3 years. The Secretary will review National Park Service programs for preservation options. The Secretary will conduct a study to identify options to preserve lighthouses in the Great Lakes States. This includes reviewing National Park Service programs and consulting with various historical and preservation entities. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose.
